comment: CA9 is identified as a key negative regulator in Alkaliptosis. CA9, which is activated by the NF-百B pathway, is thought to be a negatively regulated gene responsible for inhibiting intracellular alkalinization and resistance to Alkaliptosis.

description: ATPase H+ transporting V0 subunit d1
comment: The study used mass-spectrometry-based drug target identification and point mutation technologies to reveal that ATP6V0D1 is a direct target of the opioid analgesic drug JTC801, which drives Alkaliptosis in PDAC cells by inhibiting the STAT3-mediated lysosomal pH homeostasis.

description: acyl-CoA synthetase short chain family member 2
comment: JTC801 can up-regulate the mRNA and protein expression of ACSS2 and ACSS2 can promote NF-百B-dependent CA9 downregulation through the production of intracellular acetyl-coenzyme A and subsequent histone acetylation, leading to alkaliptosis.
ACAA2 participates in cellular biological processes by regulating cell apoptosis. Overexpression of ACAA2 can induce cell apoptosis, while shRNA interference can inhibit this process.
Under the action of hormone disruptors, the expression of ASAH2 will decrease, leading to the accumulation of ceramide in skin cells, which can cause skin inflammation and cell apoptosis

CD38 is associated with apoptosis in B cells and can regulate apoptosis by inhibiting or inducing CD38 expression.CD38 on B cells can induce proliferation and apoptosis by crosslinking related cytokines, thus playing a role in apoptosis.In chronic B-cell lymphoblastic leukemia (B-CLL),CD38 is related to cell apoptosis,ZAP-70 protein tyrosine phosphorylation,and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) phosphorylation.CD38+ B cells are highly sensitive to apoptosis inducers.

CHAC1 is a component of the unfolded protein response pathway and participates in regulating apoptosis.It is downstream of the ATF4-ATF3-CHOP signaling pathway and promotes apoptosis signaling through AIF and PARP.Overexpression of CHAC1 enhances apoptosis,while small interfering RNA targeting CHAC1 suppresses apoptosis.

Oxidized-low density lipoprotein can induce VSMC apoptosis, while H2S donor NaHS and CTH overexpression can reverse this phenomenon,while CTH knockout exacerbates this apoptosis.Western blot detection showed that the high expression of GRP78 under the action of ox-LDL indicates that CTH knockout caused endoplasmic reticulum stress, which also contributes to the occurrence of VSMC apoptosis.

description: cytochrome P450 family 1 subfamily B member 1
comment: CYP1B1 participates in Apoptosis by metabolizing melatonin to generate N-acetylserotonin (NAS), which induces mitochondria-dependent apoptosis in tumor cells.

DBH is involved in apoptosis through the expression of Casp3 protein induced by rAAV-taCasp3 virus,resulting in the death of co-expressing neurons.DBH is a specific type of neuron called ventrolateral medulla (VLM) catecholaminergic neuron,which is associated with antigen adaptive immunity and tumor growth and participates in tumor development through the viral messenger.

ENO1 participates in apoptosis by regulating PASMC apoptosis.RNA silencing ENO1 and using ENO1 inhibitor ENOblock can suppress PASMC proliferation and induce its apoptosis.Specifically, reducing ENO1 levels can increase the cleavage of PARP,caspase 3,and caspase 9,and promote the apoptotic rate through TUNEL experiment.Overexpression of ENO1 can increase PASMC's resistance to apoptotic stimuli and reduce its apoptotic rate.

FHIT mediates apoptosis in lung and cervical cancer cells.The reintroduction of FHIT induces apoptosis in all FHIT-negative cell lines,particularly in Calu-1,H460,A549 among the lung cancer cell lines and SiHa cells among cervical carcinomas.The mechanism by which FHIT induces apoptosis is through the activation of caspase-8, leading to the activation of caspase-3 and subsequent induction of apoptosis.

FXN's involvement in apoptosis is achieved through the apoptotic death of neuro cells,which is a spontaneous process of cell death typically caused by DNA damage or other severe cellular stress.When the level of FXN gene expression declines,FXN-defective cells undergo uncontrolled apoptosis.The apoptotic death of FXN-deficient cells is achieved by the activation of the neuronal apoptotic pathway.

GCLM is associated with the process of PTL-induced apoptosis in BCPAP cells and its expression is up-regulated.PRM analysis showed that the protein expression of GCLM increased in these cells,while its mRNA expression level did not change.It can be inferred that GCLM is involved in the process of PTL-induced apoptosis in BCPAP cells,and its role may be achieved by regulating the intracellular redox state.

The downregulation of GGCT inhibits the growth of MCF-7/ADR breast cancer by inducing cell apoptosis and necrosis.This might be achieved by disrupting the balance of intracellular glutathione (GSH) and thus affecting the function of Nrf2.

The expression of GPX1 is reduced in myocardial cells after I/R injury,while SalB treatment regulates the TRIM8/GPX1 pathway,promotes the expression of GPX1 protein,reduces ROS generation,and the level of cardiac cell apoptosis.At the same time,GPX1 overexpression can alleviate I/R-induced cardiac cell apoptosis.

GSTP1 participates in regulating the cell cycle and apoptosis,and the mutation status of different sites of GSTP1 also affects the apoptotic function of cells.Different haplotypes of GSTP1 have different effects on cell proliferation and apoptosis.

When cells are subjected to chronic reperfusion injury,HMOX1 may protect against cell apoptosis by inhibiting the expression of apoptotic regulators,thus exerting a protective effect on cells.After repeated ischemia/reperfusion,overexpression of HMOX1 can significantly reduce myocardial apoptosis (as confirmed by TUNEL staining,the number of TUNEL-positive cells in mouse myocardial cells undergoing repeated I/R is significantly reduced.

ICBP90 and GR participate in the formation of a 3-protein transcription factor complex at the MIF-794 CATT5-8 promoter,which elevates MIF expression to reduce apoptotic signaling.The relationship between MIF expression level and apoptosis exhibits a bell-shaped dose-response curve,where high concentrations of hormones can reduce MIF expression and promote apoptosis.The anti-apoptotic effect of MIF is achieved through the regulation of Akt and Bcl-2 expression,and differences in genes such as ICBP90 and MIF can lead to cell apoptosis or promote MIF's protective effect.

MIR132 is related to apoptosis through modulating the apoptotic process in cardiomyocytes.MIR132 can play an anti-apoptotic role by activating the phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase/protein kinase B pathway in cardiomyocytes.

MIR17 plays an important role in regulating apoptosis,and can also regulate cellular lifespan and senescence through its pleiotropic effects.Overexpression of miR-17 can inhibit cellular senescence and increase the lifespan of mice.In addition,miR-17 further inhibits cellular senescence and apoptosis by regulating the expression of the MKP7 gene.

MIR21 inhibits podocyte death by suppressing pro-apoptotic signals.TGFB1 can regulate the expression of MIR21 and suppress cell apoptosis by inhibiting the expression of BH3-only genes and promoting AKT activation. Under the stimulation of signals.TGFB1, transfection of MIR21 mimic in mouse podocytes can alleviate podocyte apoptosis.

MIR210 is closely related to the development of atherosclerosis through its role in promoting endothelial cell apoptosis.The high-fat diet upregulates MIR210 by directly targeting PDK1,inducing cell apoptosis in endothelial cells and promoting the development of atherosclerosis.

MIR221 inhibits cell apoptosis by targeting pro-apoptotic gene PUMA,thereby reducing apoptosis.Studies have shown that in human glioma cells,miR-221/222 reduce PUMA protein levels by targeting PUMA-3＊UTR,leading to cell survival. Introducing PUMA cDNA without 3∩UTR abrogated miR-221/222-induced cell survival.On the other hand,knockdown of miR-221/222 induces PUMA expression and significantly reduces cell apoptosis,which can significantly decrease tumor growth in xenograft model.

MIR222 regulates apoptosis in glioblastoma and may be potential therapeutic targets for cancer treatment.MIR-222 reduces PUMA protein levels by targeting PUMA-3'UTR, thereby inhibiting apoptosis and promoting cell survival in human glioblastoma cells. Injection of As-miR-221/222 can reduce tumor growth and induce cell apoptosis.

NDUFA13 has a regulatory effect on apoptosis.It has been found that a moderate down-regulation of NDUFA13 can provide cell protection against apoptosis through the use of reactive oxygen species (ROS) as a second messenger,ultimately reducing superoxide burst and decreasing infarct size during ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury.In addition,down-regulated NDUFA13 resulted in the activation of STAT3 signaling,which has been shown to increase survival in tumor cells.

NDUFS3 plays a role in apoptosis by regulating the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in MRC complex I.IFN-b and RA have synergistic apoptotic effects in cancer treatment,but the mechanism of action is unclear.The study found that IFN-b/RA upregulates the expression of MRC complex subunits,including NDUFS3,which modulate ROS production and late gene expression,leading to cell death.Knockdown of NDUFS3 leads to a decrease in ROS production and apoptosis in cancer cell lines.The MRC is essential for apoptosis,regulating ROS production and cytochrome c release.

Overexpression of NOS3 can lead to neuronal apoptosis.Overexpression of NOS3 can cause an increase in the levels of several proteins,including p53, p21/Waf1,Bax,and CD95,which leads to mitochondrial dysfunction and an increase in cellular oxidative stress levels.These adverse effects are related to the instability of the endoplasmic reticulum and even the cell membrane,rather than directly related to the synthesis of NO.

PRODH induces apoptosis through the generation of ROS, especially superoxide radicals, via the mitochondrial pathway. It also activates the extrinsic or death receptor pathway to induce cell death. In colorectal cancer cells, PRODH induces the expression of TRAIL and DR5 as well as cleavage of caspase-8. NFAT signaling pathway has a regulatory role in PRODH-mediated TRAIL activation while MEK/ERK signaling pathway is involved.

PTEN is involved in regulating the expression of Bnip3 and HIF-2汐, which induces cell apoptosis and cavity formation. The results of the study suggest a new molecular mechanism for PTEN in promoting apoptosis and lumen formation during epithelial morphogenesis independently of its phosphatase activity.
In the diabetic retina, nitration and inactivation of PTGIS are important mechanisms leading to cell apoptosis and vascular pathology changes.

Mats, a protein in the SGMS1 protein family, acts as a tumor suppressor in Drosophila, controlling cell proliferation and apoptosis. Mats works in conjunction with Large tumor suppressor/Warts protein kinase to regulate cell proliferation and apoptosis. Mats physically associates with Warts to stimulate the catalytic activity of the Warts kinase. Loss of Mats function resulted in increased cell proliferation, defective apoptosis, and induction of tissue overgrowth.

The mechanism of SGPL1 involved in Apoptosis is that SGPL1 increases stress-induced ceramide generation and apoptosis by reducing intracellular S1P. At the same time, enzymatic activity is also a necessary factor in promoting Apoptosis. Overexpression of SGPL1 can increase stress-induced ceramide generation and apoptosis.

SGPP1 participates in Apoptosis by regulating intra- and extracellular S1P levels, thereby affecting cell growth resistance. Knockdown of endogenous SGPP1 causes S1P accumulation, leading to significant resistance to cytotoxic agents and reduced apoptosis.

SIRT1 participates in apoptosis of nucleus pulposus cells. Apoptosis of intervertebral disc cells caused by mechanical overload is a core cause of intervertebral disc degeneration. The results showed that high-magnitude compression triggers cellular apoptosis and reduces the expression levels of SIRT1 and microtubule-associated protein-1 light chain-3B (LC3B) in rat NPCs. However, SIRT1 overexpression in NPCs partly reduced these indicators. The upregulation of SIRT1 increases the formation of the LC3B/Fas complex, which suppresses NPC apoptosis by inhibiting the NF-百B pathway under high compressive stress, and reduces activation of the NF-百B pathway. The study suggests that SIRT1 plays a major role in the regulation of various cellular processes related to oxidative stress, metabolism, cell senescence, apoptosis, and autophagy.

TXNDC12 exhibits cytoprotective effects against H2O2-induced apoptosis in FHM cells. The overexpression of EaTXNDC12 results in significant cell survival compared with the empty pcDNA3.1(+) with different concentrations of H2O2.
VNN1 attenuates Ox-LDL-induced apoptosis by upregulating p53 expression and downregulating BCL-2 expression.

CYCS is an important component of the apoptosome, which initiates the caspase cascade to induce apoptosis. In addition, zinc can negatively regulate the promoter transcriptional activity of CYCS through MTF-1 and HNF-1汐, downregulate the mRNA and total protein expression of CYCS.

GPX4 is involved in apoptosis regulation by modulating the mitochondrial pathway. Knockdown of GPX4 downregulates the anti-apoptotic proteins Bcl-2 and Bcl-xl while upregulating the apoptotic proteins Bax and Bim. Moreover, GPX4 induces apoptosis through up-regulation of EGR1 in TNBC cells.

The researchers found that a recurrent activating mutation in the PLCG gene has a frequency of 30% in patients with primary cardiac angiosarcomas. Experiments on the PLCG1 gene showed that this mutation increases the apoptosis resistance and invasiveness of endothelial cells. In addition, processes such as diabetes, vaccination, oxidative stress can activate the PLCG1 gene and enhance cell survival.

MIR506 induces autophagy-related cell death in pancreatic cancer by targeting the STAT3 pathway. The study found that MIR506 downregulation significantly correlates with disease progression in PDAC and that its expression is associated with a patient's overall survival rate. The results from this study identified MIR506 as a new tumor suppressor in PDAC by inducing autophagy-related cell death through the STAT3 pathway.

MIR100 can promote autophagy in endothelial cells by regulating mTOR and Raptor and interacting directly with the transcription factor TFEB. MIR100 enhances autophagy while reducing IKK汕 kinase protein expression, leading to a decrease in NF-百B p65 subunit expression. Bafilomycin, an autophagy inhibitor, interferes with the anti-inflammatory effects of MIR100 on IKK汕 kinase signaling by mTOR inhibition, suggesting that the anti-inflammatory effects of MIR100 depend on autophagy in endothelial cells.

MIR132 plays an anti-autophagic role in the process of cardiomyocyte autophagy. Studies show that overexpression of miR-212/132 family can reduce the autophagic response of cardiomyocytes, leading to cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure. Pharmacological inhibition of MIR132 can rescue cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure, providing a new therapeutic target for the treatment of heart failure.

MIR137 has been found to inhibit autophagy and enhance the sensitivity of pancreatic cancer cells to chemotherapy drugs, and negatively regulate the formation of autophagy by targeting ATG5. Autophagy is a process by which cellular components are broken down and recycled for cellular biosynthesis, which can protect cancer cells from stressful conditions and contribute to chemoresistance. MIR137 can inhibit mitophagy, the selective degradation of mitochondria, via regulation of two receptors.

MIR140 is involved in mediating chondrocyte growth, apoptosis, and autophagy by regulating cellular autophagy levels.In human primary chondrocytes, MIR140 promotes cell autophagy activity via regulating FUT1. The results suggest that MIR140/149 mimic transfection activates mitochondrial/endogenous autophagy pathways, while inhibiting MIR140/149 suppresses chondrocyte autophagy activity.

MIR142 is a miRNA that can post-transcriptionally regulate the human autophagy gene ATG16L1. The regulatory mechanism decreases ATG16L1 mRNA and protein levels, thereby regulating autophagy by targeting ATG16L1 in human colonic epithelial cells. MIR142 inhibits starvation- and L18-MDP-induced autophagic activity, while a MIR142 inhibitor enhances starvation-induced autophagy in Jurkat T cells.

MIR143 is related to autophagy in drug abuse-induced neurotoxicity. Experiments suggest that Methamphetamine regulates the expression of MIR143. MIR143 regulates the expression of BBC3 on paste cells, and regulates the balance of autophagy and apoptosis. MIR143 enhances autophagy by down-regulating BBC3.
MIR144 suppresses autophagy by post-transcriptional regulation of the DRAM2 gene in human primary monocytes, which reduces the innate immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

MIR149 is related to autophagy through the regulation of FUT1. MIR149 promotes the proliferation and autophagy of human primary chondrocytes by downregulating FUT1. In rapamycin-induced autophagic chondrocytes, transfection of MIR149 mimic can significantly increase LC3II, Atg5, and Beclin-1 protein levels, and MIR149 can regulate this process by targeting FUT1.

MIR152 is a miRNA that regulates autophagy induced by cisplatin in ovarian cancer cells. Studies have shown that MIR152 reduces intracellular autophagic products by inhibiting the expression of ATG14, thereby affecting the sensitivity of cells to chemotherapy drugs. When MIR152 is expressed more, autophagy activity is lower, and the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs such as cisplatin is higher. This suggests that downregulation of MIR152 can affect autophagy and increase the chemotherapy resistance of cells.

Alcohol targets multiple steps in the autophagy pathway, including LAMP1 and LAMP2, to decrease autophagy flux, leading to impaired autophagy in ALD and alcoholic hepatitis (AH) mouse models, as well as in human livers with ALD. Alcohol-induced miR-155 was found to target different genes in the autophagy pathway and regulate exosome production.

MIR17 is a factor that inhibits autophagy. The study shows that MIR17 suppresses autophagy by downregulating DDX5 and exacerbates the occurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma. MIR17 stimulates p62 expression and inhibits LC3B-II conversion, thereby inhibiting autophagy.
It is found that MIR182 can promote the inflammatory response of Caco-2 cells by inhibiting autophagy. MIR182 can influence the autophagy pathway by interacting with circRNA HECTD1.

Studies have shown that miR-183 regulates autophagy and apoptosis in gastric cancer cells by targeting the UVRAG gene's 3' untranslated region, affecting cell proliferation. UVRAG may interact with members of the Bcl-2 family during cell death and may mediate autophagy.

MIR186 was found to be negatively associated with autophagy-related protein ATG14. It was found that MIR186 can directly bind to SNHG14 to inhibit its function, thereby promoting the expression of ATG14. ATG14 can directly act as a downstream effector of the SNHG14/MIR186 axis. In addition, it has been shown that ATG14 can promote cancer cell resistance to chemotherapy by regulating autophagy in cells.

MIR188 regulates autophagy and cell death through targeting ATG7, a key autophagy promoting gene, in cardiomyocytes. MIR188 inhibits autophagy and cell death induced by anoxia/reoxygenation, which is related to myocardial infarction. Autophagy-promoting factor (APF), a long noncoding RNA, inhibits the activity of MIR188 by directly binding to it, leading to the regulation of ATG7 expression and the consequent cardiac autophagy through MIR188. APF modulates autophagic programme and autophagic cell death through targeting the MIR188/ATG7 pathway.

The decreased expression level of MIR191 may contribute to the formation of radiation-resistant lung cancer cells through mediating cellular autophagy. Beclin-1, a protein in the Autophagy pathway, has a potential binding relationship with MIR191 in lung cancer cells. When the expression level of MIR191 increases, it negatively regulates Beclin-1, inhibits cellular autophagy, and suppresses the proliferation and growth of lung cancer cells.

In asthmatic mice, overexpression of MIR192 attenuated autophagy by decreasing the expression of ATG7, LC3II/I, and beclin-1 and increasing the expression of p62. In addition, MIR192's target ATG7 promoted the proliferation of smooth muscle cells in asthma patients and alleviated the decrease in proliferation caused by MIR192.
An increase in MIR195 levels can inhibit the selective autophagy of tight junction proteins in the blood-brain barrier, thus helping to maintain BBB integrity.

MIR204 can regulate the starvation autophagy of cells by directly inhibiting TRPM3 and CAV1, as well as directly inhibiting the accumulation of LC3B. At the same time, the expression level of MIR204 is also regulated by VHL.

The study found that MIR205 can regulate autophagy of AMs by controlling E2F1, thereby inhibiting pulmonary fibrosis, and the E2F1/SKP2/Beclin1 axis is the regulatory mechanism of MIR205 in this process.
MIR21 can inhibit autophagy by regulating PTEN and increase the proliferation, migration, and invasion of bladder cancer T24 cells.

MIR210 promotes the process of epithelial-mesenchymal transition and induces oncogenic autophagy in osteosarcoma. By downregulating the expression of PIK3R5 and regulating the AKT/mTOR signaling pathway, MIR210 promotes EMT and oncogenic autophagy in osteosarcoma.

The MIR212 has an anti-autophagic function in cardiomyocytes in regulating FOXO3 expression, reducing autophagy levels in myocardial cells under starvation. Overexpression of miRNA-212/132 inhibits the autophagic response of cardiomyocytes, leading to cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure.

MIR214 is a regulatory molecule that can directly bind to the 3' untranslated region of the ULK1 gene and suppress its expression. Increased expression of MIR214 leads to decreased expression of autophagy-related genes such as ULK1, ULK2, ATG7, and ATG16L1, causing a decrease in autophagic response. Inhibition of MIR214 can indirectly increase autophagic response by increasing the expression of ULK1 and HNF4A, thus alleviating hepatic steatosis and increasing autophagosome formation and MAP1LC3/LC3-II protein levels.

MIR215 induces autophagy by targeting PI3K and activating ROS-MAPK pathways in cardiomyocytes. It can regulate the PI3K/AKT/TOR pathway by downregulating PI3K and activating autophagy related genes. In addition, MIR215 can induce the expression of autophagy related genes by increasing ROS accumulation and activating MAPK pathways.

MIR22 may act as an important switch between autophagy and apoptosis to regulate 5-FU sensitivity.MIR22 inhibits autophagy and promotes apoptosis induced by 5-FU treatment, thus increasing the sensitivity of CRC cells to 5-FU. MIR22 can regulate the autophagy pathway by post-transcriptional silencing of BTG1, thereby affecting tumor survival and resistance.

Upregulation of MIR221/222 can inhibit Dex-induced autophagy. MIR221/222 inhibits autophagy by directly targeting ATG12 and the p27kip-mTOR pathway. Dex leads to the downregulation of MIR221/222, which induces autophagy and cell death in MM cells.

MIR224 is an oncogenic factor involved in hepatocellular carcinoma tumorigenesis, but Autophagy can suppress HCC by selectively degrading MIR224. Both MIR224 and CCND1 are regulated by Autophagy degradation machinery. MIR224 is preferentially adsorbed to autophagosomes by unknown factors, while CCND1 is selectively adsorbed to autophagosomes through the SQSTM1 pathway for subsequent degradation.

Through in vitro and in vivo experiments, the researchers found that ADMSC-EVs promote post-stroke recovery and reduce autophagic response by regulating MIR25. Transfection of MIR25 mimics can inhibit autophagy regulation and increase cell survival, while transfection of MIR25 inhibitors can increase autophagy regulation and decrease cell survival.

MIR31 is involved in Autophagy regulation by controlling PP2A activity. Studies have shown that Mir155 and Mir31 are regulated by MTOR to control PP2A levels, thereby affecting the activity of GSK3B and promoting the activation of the WNT-SHH signaling pathway, leading to the expression of ALOXs and ultimately inhibiting Autophagy.

MIR32 inhibits autophagy in vascular smooth muscle cells by inhibiting MEF2D expression, thereby promoting cellular osteogenic differentiation and vascular calcification. MIR32 can be released from macrophages via EVs and is upregulated under high glucose conditions. After MIR32 mimics transfection, autophagy marker genes were significantly decreased while osteogenic marker genes were significantly increased.

MTM1-UBQLN2 complex can recognize misfolded intermediate filaments proteins, such as desmin and vimentin, and promote their degradation independently of Autophagy. MTM1 interacts with Proteasome to facilitate the degradation of misfolded intermediate filament, instead of being related to Autophagy.

MTMR4 is mainly distributed in late endosomes and autophagosomes, and regulates endocytic and autophagic pathways by down-regulating the level of phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate (PI(3)P). Knockdown of MTMR4 impairs endosomal maturation, autophagy, and activates TFEB to regulate lysosomal protein gene expression. Detailed experiments are carried out on cell culture, transfection, immunostaining, quantitative real-time PCR, and microscopy. MTMR4 deficiency disrupts endosomal traffic and the autophagy process.

The MTMR8/R9 complex regulates the levels of PtdIns(3)P in cells and therefore affects autophagy. Overexpression of MTMR8 plus R9 inhibits autophagy. In addition, knockdown of MTMR8 and MTMR9 significantly reduces the level of p62 in cells, which is a protein degraded in autophagosomes and is used to monitor autophagy.

UFC1 mediates the degradation of UFMylated substrate proteins and is involved in the process of ER-phagy. This means that the presence of UFC1 can promote the degradation and utilization of damaged proteins and organelles in cells through the autophagy mechanism.
MiR-330-3p levels are significantly reduced during IRI, and it interacts with phosphoglycerate mutase family member 5 to regulate mitophagy.
MiR-335-5p can alleviate inflammatory response, airway fibrosis, and autophagy in childhood asthma through targeted regulation of ATG5.

MIR-373 is related to autophagy. MIR-373 can regulate autophagy by inhibiting the expression of METTL3 and releasing TFEB. CREB can alleviate autophagic blockage and cell apoptosis by regulating the expression of MIR-373, thus relieving osteoarthritis injury.
MiR-373 is a key regulating factor that directly targets METTL3 and facilitates the release of specific proteins (TFEB) that maintain the survival and autophagy levels of chondrocytes.

Autophagy facilitates the survival of liver cancer cells exposed to hypoxia, but downregulated MIR375 inhibits autophagy activation under hypoxic conditions, which restricts tumour growth. Restoring MIR375's function impairs tumour cell viability, suppresses mitophagy, and hence retards tumour growth.

K73-03 can regulate SPINK1 transcription by up-regulating MIR421, leading to down-regulation of the expression of autophagy regulator Beclin-1 and the occurrence of autophagy. Furthermore, K73-03 can inhibit the growth of pancreatic cancer cells and induce apoptosis by inducing autophagy and mitochondrial damage.

MIR423-5p was validated as a positive regulator of autophagy in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell lines following Sorafenib treatment.upregulation was both in vitro and in vivo by Sorafenib treatment, and its increase correlated with response to therapy. HCC cells transfected with MIR showed an increase in autophagic cells, and therefore may be useful in the sensitisation of HCC cells to Sorafenib.

MIR484 regulates mitochondrial network by targeting Fis1.MIR484 regulates mitochondrial biogenesis, function, and fission and participates in regulating gene expression, such as FoxO transcription factors. MIR484 is thus linked to autophagy through these mechanisms.
MIR502 plays a role in regulating Autophagy by inhibiting the key mediator Rab1B, inhibiting the growth of colon cancer cells.

MIR503 can regulate the occurrence of autophagy through the PKA/mTOR signaling pathway. MIR503 triggers autophagy by targeting the PRKACA protein, thereby preventing the proliferation and metastasis of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma cells.
Through bioinformatics analysis of the TCGA database, MIR615 was negatively correlated with the expression of MICA and MICB, and might be one of the regulatory factors of these genes.
MIR877-3P can protect vascular endothelial cells from high glucose-induced autophagy, thereby reducing endothelial cell damage.
MIR885 is a miRNA that regulates TIGAR expression and promotes liver cancer cell proliferation and cell cycle while inhibiting apoptosis and autophagy, enhancing resistance to chemotherapy.
MIR93 is differentially expressed in Proneural (PN) and Mesenchymal (MES) subtypes, with higher levels in PN GBM, which is associated with better survival for GBM patients.

The expression of the autophagy signaling molecule mTOR decreases as a result of TiO2 NPs, and miR-96-5p is one of the regulating factors. When the expression of miR-96-5p increases, it targets mTOR and regulates its expression, triggering autophagy in the cells. In addition, miR-96-5p can also target Bcl-2 and affect cell apoptosis.
ATIC inhibits autophagy through the AKT/FOXO3 pathway and promotes the progression of liver cancer in vitro and in vivo.

MTMR14 plays an important role in regulating autophagy as a type of myotubularin protein. The modification of PIs is an important mechanism for controlling organelle and membrane traffic, and they also play an important role in the regulation of autophagy. The study explored the correlation between MTMR14 and autophagy dysregulation through double knockdown of MTMR14, which could explain certain pathological conditions such as centronuclear myopathy. The authors also discuss the function of MTMR14 as a modifier of disease severity, rather than a primary cause.

P53 directly regulates the transcription of ACER2, significantly stimulating ACER2 expression, and ACER2-mediated autophagy and apoptosis are found to be connected with ROS generation. The interaction of ACER2 with autophagy drives its impact on apoptosis. ACER2 induces autophagy and apoptosis through the production of ROS.

LncPVT1 directly interacted with miR-214-3p to impede its role as a sponge of GPX4. Depletion of lncPVT1 accelerated the ferroptosis of live cancer cells, whereas miR-214-3p inhibition and GPX4 overexpression reversed this effect. Ketamine-induced cell growth suppression and ferroptosis were also suppressed by miR-214-3p inhibition and GPX4 overexpression.

Over-expression of H19 suppressed cell viability and promoted ferroptosis of BMVECs. miR-106b-5p is predicted to be a target of H19. The expression of miR-106b-5p was lower in oxygen and glucose deprivation hemin-treated (OGD/H-treated) cells. Over-expression of miR-106b-5p reversed the effects of H19 on cell viability and ferroptosis in BMVECs. Furthermore, acyl-CoA synthetase long-chain family member 4 (ACSL4) was verified to be a target gene of miR-106b-5p and was highly expressed in OGD/H-treated cells. Upregulation of ACSL4 inhibited the effects of miR-106b-5p and induced BMVEC dysfunction.

Moreover, paeonol notably inhibited ferroptosis in hemin-treated neuronal cells via inhibition of ACSL4. Additionally, HOTAIR bound to UPF1, and UPF1 promoted the degradation of ACSL4 by binding to ACSL4. comment: Knockdown of MEG8 increased the miR-497-5p expression and reduced the mRNA and protein levels of NOTCH2. Using a dual-luciferase assay, we confirmed the binding between MEG8 and miR-497-5p, and between the miR-497-5p and 3'UTR of NOTCH2. We further found that silencing MEG8 significantly decreased the expressions of SLC7A11 and GPX4 both in mRNA and protein level and had no effect on the level of AIFM2. Importantly, blocking miR-497-5p abrogated the effects of MEG8 loss on cell viability, MDA level and expression levels of NOTCH2, SLC7A11 and GPX4 in HemECs. Taken together, our results suggested that knockdown of long non-coding RNA MEG8 inhibited the proliferation and induced the ferroptosis of hemangioma endothelial cells by regulating miR-497-5p/NOTCH2 axis.

Erastin-induced cell death was positively correlated with ACSL4 level. NEAT1 regulated levels of ACSL4 and proteins related to the ferroptosis and classical apoptosis pathways. Levels of ACSL4, SLC7A11, and GPX4 were decreased more by NEAT1 silencing plus erastin than by erastin alone.

H19 expression was positively correlated with Bcl-2 and GPX4 expression and negatively linked with Bax levels. It was demonstrated that silencing H19 downregulated Bcl-2 and GPX4 expression and upregulated Bax expression at both the mRNA and protein levels in HTR-8/SVneo trophoblast cells. In conclusion, the present findings suggested that H19 has important roles in SA by promoting apoptosis and ferroptosis.

We found that the levels of PVT1 were upregulated and miR-214 levels were downregulated in plasma of AIS patients. NIHSS score was positively correlated with PVT1 levels but was negatively with miR-214 levels. PVT1 silencing or miR-214 overexpression significantly reduced infarct size and suppressed ferroptosis in vivo. miR-214 overexpression markedly decreased PVT1 levels. Specifically, miR-214 could bind to 3'untranslated region (3'UTR) of PVT1, TP53 or TFR1. PVT1 overexpression or miR-214 silencing markedly abolished the effects of Ferrostatin-1 on ferroptosis indicators except for TFR1 expression. Besides, miR-214 silencing counteracted the effects of PVT1 knockdown on the ferroptosis-related proteins.
Silencing of lncRNA ZFAS1 attenuated ferroptosis and PF progression by lncRNA ZFAS1 acting as a competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA) and sponging miR-150-5p to downregulate SLC38A1 expression.

Autophagy inducers and H19 can reverse the production of lipid reactive oxygen species and the inhibition of autophagy induced by metformin. The present study suggests that metformin may induce ferroptosis by inhibiting autophagy via H19, and this discovery may facilitate the development of novel therapies for the treatment of breast cancer.

We aimed to investigate the functions and mechanisms of miR-539 in CRC proliferation. Functionally, miR-539 can bind to and regulate the expression of TIPE, and miR-539 activates SAPK/JNK to downregulate the expression of glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4) and promote ferroptosis. Our data reveal the novel role of miR-539 in regulating ferroptosis in CRC via activation of the SAPK/JNK axis, providing new insight into the mechanism of abnormal proliferation in CRC and a novel potential therapeutic target for advanced CRC.

miR-670-3p level was elevated in human glioblastoma, but decreased upon ferroptotic stimulation. miR-670-3p inhibitor suppressed, while miR-670-3p mimic promoted glioblastoma cell growth through modulating ferroptosis. Mechanistically, ACSL4 was required for the regulation on ferroptosis and growth of glioblastoma cells by miR-670-3p. Moreover, U87MG and A172 cells treated with miR-670-3p inhibitor showed an increased chemosensitivity to TMZ.

MiR-382-5p/SLC7A11 axis was involved in lidocaine-mediated inhibition of ovarian and breast cancer cell proliferation in vitro. The miR-382-5p expression was down-regulated but SLC7A11 expression was up-regulated in clinical ovarian and breast cancer samples. Furthermore, the treatment of lidocaine repressed tumor growth of ovarian cancer cells in vivo, in which the miR-382-5p expression was increased while SLC7A11 expression was decreased. Consequently, we concluded that the lidocaine promoted ferroptosis by miR-382-5p/SLC7A11 axis in ovarian and breast cancer cells.

microarray and bioinformatics analysis were performed to search the potential targets of miR-375 in GC cells. Luciferase reporter, RNA immunoprecipitation, and RNA-FISH assays were carried out to verify the targeting of miR-375. Subsequently, combined with tissue microarray analysis, erastin-resistant GC cells, transmission electron microscopy, a series of agonists and oxidative stress markers, the underlying mechanisms contributing to miR-375-mediated effects were explored.

We identified the glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4) gene as the direct target of miR-324-3p, where overexpression of the gene reversed the miR-324-3p effect of sensitizing the A549/DDP cells to cisplatin. Furthermore, the GPX4 inhibitor RSL3 could mimic the effect of miR-324-3p upregulation in increasing the sensitivity of the cisplatin-resistant cells to the drug. Significantly, miR-324-3p enhanced cisplatin-induced ferroptosis in the A549/DDP cells.

The luciferase 3'-untranslated region reporter results identified FTH1 as the direct target of miR-335. The silencing of FTH1 in 6-OHDA-stimulated cells enhanced the effects of miR-335 on ferroptosis and promoted PD pathology. Mechanistically, miR-335 enhanced ferroptosis through the degradation of FTH1 to increase iron release, lipid peroxidation and reactive oxygen species (ROS) accumulation, and to decrease mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP).

Overexpression of miR-324-3p inhibited cancer cell viability. miR-324-3p inhibitor promoted cell viability. Further studies showed that the effect of miR-324-3p was mediated by directly targeting glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4). miR-324-3p bound to the 3雿?UTR of GPX4 and led to the downregulation of GPX4. In vivo studies showed that metformin induced ferroptosis by upregulating miR-324-3p in the xenograft model of breast cancer in mice.

We identified that miR-182-5p and miR-378a-3p were upregulated in the ferroptosis and H/R-induced injury, and correlates reversely with glutathione peroxidases 4 (GPX4) and solute carrier family 7 member 11 (SLC7A11) expression in renal I/R injury tissues, respectively. In vitro studies showed that miR-182-5p and miR-378a-3p induced ferroptosis in cells. We further found that miR-182-5p and miR-378a-3p regulated the expression of GPX4 and SLC7A11 negatively by directly binding to the 3'UTR of GPX4 and SLC7A11 mRNA. In vivo study showed that silencing miR-182-5p and miR-378a-3p alleviated the I/R-induced renal injury in rats.

miR-137 overexpression boosts the neuroprotective effects of EPC-EXs against apoptosis and mitochondrial dysfunction in oxyHb-treated SH-SY5Y cells. Furthermore, EXsmiR-137 rather than EXs can restore the decrease in miR-137 levels and inhibit ferroptosis, and the protection mechanism might involve the miR-137-COX2/PGE2 signaling pathway.

We show that miR-424-5p negatively regulates ferroptosis by directly targeting ACSL4 in ovarian cancer cells. Upregulation of miR-424-5p suppressed ACSL4 by directly binding to its 3'-UTR, which subsequently reduced erastin- and RSL3-induced ferroptosis. Meanwhile, knockdown of miR-424-5p increased the sensitivity of ovarian cancer cells to erastin and RSL3. Furthermore, ACSL4 was upregulated in ovarian cancer tissues, and high ACSL4 expression predicted worse prognosis and sensitized ovarian cancer cells to erastin- and RSL3-induced ferroptosis. Importantly, decreases in lipid peroxides and ferroptotic cell death mediated by miR-424-5p could be abrogated by ACSL4 overexpression.

We found that ferroptosis inducers erastin and RSL3 increased NEAT1 expression by promoting the binding of p53 to the NEAT1 promoter. Induced NEAT1 promoted the expression of MIOX by competitively binding to miR-362-3p. MIOX increased ROS production and decreased the intracellular levels of NADPH and GSH, resulting in enhanced erastin- and RSL3-induced ferroptosis. Importantly, overexpression of NEAT1 increased the anti-tumor activity of erastin and RSL3 by enhancing ferroptosis both in vitro and in vivo.

Overexpression of lncRNA H19 eliminated the anticancer effect of curcumenol, while lncRNA H19 knockdown promoted ferroptosis induced by curcumenol treatment. Mechanistically, we showed that lncRNA H19 functioned as a competing endogenous RNA to bind to miR-19b-3p, thereby enhanced the transcription activity of its endogenous target, ferritin heavy chain 1 (FTH1), a marker of ferroptosis. In conclusion, our data show that the natural product curcumenol exerted its antitumor effects on lung cancer by triggering ferroptosis, and the lncRNA H19/miR-19b-3p/FTH1 axis plays an essential role in curcumenol-induced ferroptotic cell death.

miR-140-5p is abundant in obese ATM-Exos and promotes ferroptosis in cardiomyocytes. Solute carrier family 7 member 11 (SLC7A11) is a downstream target of miR-140-5p, which induces ferroptosis via inhibition of GSH synthesis by targeting SLC7A11. Attenuating exosomal-miR-140-5p expression alleviates ferroptosis and cardiac injury induced by obese ATM exosomes by alleviating GSH inhibition.

miR-1287-5p expression was downregulated in human osteosarcoma, but upregulated upon ferroptotic stimulation. Overexpression of miR-1287-5p significantly induced, while inhibition of miR-1287-5p suppressed ferroptosis of osteosarcoma cells, thereby modulating cell viability and colony formation. Mechanistic studies indicated that miR-1287-5p directly bound to the 3'-untranslated region of glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4) to inhibit its protein level and activity, and that GPX4 overexpression completely abolished the miR-1287-5p mimic-mediated ferroptotic induction and tumor suppression. Moreover, the miR-1287-5p mimic dramatically sensitized human osteosarcoma cells to cisplatin chemotherapy.

The relationship between TEC ferroptosis and cisplatin-induced AKI was investigated in vitro and in vivo. Ferrostatin-1(Fer-1), an inhibitor of ferroptosis, was observed to confer a protective effect against the renal tubular injury and renal failure induced by cisplatin. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) regulate the genes that have important functions in the development of cis-AKI. In the present study, GPX4 was predicted as a target of miR-214-3p. Moreover, inhibiting miR-214-3p enhanced the expressions of GPX4 and SLC7A11 while decreasing the ACSL4 expression. Furthermore, miR-214-3p down-regulation protected against TEC death and renal tubule damage both in vitro and in vivo.

MiRNAs expression profile of melanoma cells in IFN-蝥?driven ferroptosis was first obtained. Then, upregulated miR-21-3p was proved to facilitate IFN-蝥?mediated ferroptosis by potentiating lipid peroxidation. miR-21-3p increased the ferroptosis sensitivity by directly targeting thioredoxin reductase 1 (TXNRD1) to enhance lipid reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. Furthermore, miR-21-3p overexpression in tumor synergized with anti-PD-1 antibody by promoting tumor cell ferroptosis. More importantly, miR-21-3p-loaded gold nanoparticles were constructed, and the systemic delivery of them increased the efficacy of anti-PD-1 antibody without prominent side effects in preclinical mice model. Ultimately, ATF3 was found to promote miR-21-3p transcription in IFN-蝥?driven ferroptosis.

Further study showed that TFRC was a target of miR-222, and miR-222 promoted LX-2 cell activation through suppressing TFRC-induced ferroptosis in LX-2 cells. Exosomal miR-222 derived from HBV-infected hepatocytes promoted LF through inhibiting TFRC and TFRC-induced ferroptosis.

miR-93-5p was upregulated in the GCs of PCOS patients. Overexpression of miR-93-5p promoted apoptosis and ferroptosis in KGN cells, while knockdown of miR-93-5p showed the reverse effect. Resveratrol improved LPS-induced endotoxemia cardiomyocyte injury by upregulating miR-149 and inhibiting ferroptosis. Resveratrol inhibited HMGB1 expression by upregulating miR-149. HMGB1 upregulation reversed the inhibitory effect of miR-149 on LPS-induced ferroptosis in cardiomyocytes. Resveratrol upregulated miR-149 and downregulated HMGB1 to inhibit ferroptosis and improve myocardial injury in mice with LPS-induced endotoxemia. Collectively, resveratrol upregulated miR-149, downregulated HMGB1, and inhibited the ferroptosis pathway, thus improving cardiomyocyte injury in LPS-induced endotoxemia.

MiR-142-3p was highly expressed in HBV-infected HCC patients and HBV-infected M1-type macrophages. Inhibition of miR-142-3p or overexpression of SLC3A2 reversed ferroptosis and inhibited the proliferation, migration, and invasion of HCC cells.

Knockdown of NEAT1 elevated viability and GSH level in PD cell model and reduced ROS, MDA, and Fe2+ levels. Moreover, NEAT1 functioned as a sponge to suppress miR_?150_?5p expression. Moreover, miR_?150_?5p overexpression suppressed ferroptosis in PD cell model. We subsequently found that miR_?150_?5p regulated SLC7A11 expression by directly binding to BAP1. miR_?150_?5p inhibition or BAP1 overexpression mitigated the anti_交_erroptosis effect meditated by sh_交_EAT1. Taken together, knockdown of NEAT1 mitigated MPP+_交_nduced ferroptosis through regulating BAP1/SLC7A11 axis by sponging miR_?150_?5p, indicating the potential of NEAT1 as a promising therapeutic target for PD.

We validated that ZFAS1 may act as a competing endogenous RNA by competitively binding with microRNA-7-5p (miR-7-5p) and modulating the expression of its downstream molecule acyl-CoA synthetase long-chain family member 4 (ACSL4), which is now identified as a classic driver gene of ferroptosis process. In conclusion, our results demonstrate that HG-induced ZFAS1 elevation activates ferroptosis in hRECs and the ZFAS1/miR-7-5p/ACSL4 axis may serve as a therapeutic target for endothelial dysfunction in DR.

The underlying mechanism was found to be the downregulation of GPX4, independent of p53, that occurs during ICS II-induced ferroptosis. Overexpression of GPX4 reversed the ferroptosis induced by ICS II. Moreover, ICS II treatment resulted in the upregulation of miR-324-3p, which directly targets GPX4. Overall, our results suggested that ICS II-induced ferroptosis via the miR-324-3p/GPX4 axis in RCC cells could be a promising therapeutic agent for RCC.

In the I/R rat model and CF cell model, miR-375-3p promoted fibrosis by accelerating the ferroptosis of cardiomyocytes through mediating glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4). Furthermore, we treated the rats or cell model with miR-375-3p antagomir (or inhibitor) and ferroptosis inhibitor Ferrostatin-1 (Fer-1). The results showed that miR-375-3p antagomir (or inhibitor) and Fer-1 promoted the antioxidant capacity of cardiac fibroblasts, reduced GPX4-mediated ferroptosis process and alleviated I/R-induced CF.

Erastin could dose-dependently induce neuron injury and ferroptosis of LUHMES cells. miR-494-3p overexpression induced ROS production, mitochondrial damage, ferroptosis, and neuron injury in erastin-induced LUHMES cells. Likewise, miR-494-3p inhibition had the opposite effects. We also showed that REST was a target gene of miR-494-3p and could repress erastin-induced ferroptosis, neuron injury, ROS, and mitochondrial injury via SP1 in LUHMES cells. Moreover, we demonstrated that SP1 could interact with ACSL4. We also confirmed that miR-494-3p could aggravate the pathological changes of substantia nigra and corpus striatum in the MPTP-induced PD mouse model.

Expression levels of miR-127-5p and JAM3 were analyzed by RT-qPCR. GPX4 expression was quantified by western blotting. Results. miR-127-5p was expressed at low levels in IOMM-Lee cells, while JAM3 was highly expressed in IOMM-Lee cells. A dual luciferase assay demonstrated that miR-127-5p could target JAM3. Upregulation of miR-127-5p in IOMM-Lee cells resulted in cell cycle arrest and inhibition of cell activity. Upregulation of miR-127-5p increased LDH, MDA, and ROS levels and Fe2+ content and inhibited the expression of GPX4 protein. Upregulation of JAM3 reversed the results of miR-127-5p upregulation. Conclusion. miR-127-5p regulated meningioma formation and ferroptosis through JAM3, providing insights for the development of new treatments for meningioma.

RT-qPCR results showed that miR-132 was significantly up-regulated in atherosclerotic plaques compared with normal vascular samples (P < 0.001). Compared with control HUVECs, HUVECs overexpressing miR-132 showed a significantly increased level of intracellular ROS (P < 0.001), and most of ROS was colocalized with mitochondria. HUVECs overexpressing miR-132 also showed significantly decreased MMP (P < 0.001) and obviously increased mtROS (P < 0.001) and opening of mPTP (P < 0.001), which led to mitochondrial REDOX respiratory chain stress disorder. The key iron death protein GPX4 was significantly down-regulated and the oxidized protein NOX4 was significantly increased in miR-132-overexpressing HUVECs.

Propofol upregulated miR-744-5p/miR-615-3p to inhibit GPX4 transcription. Upregulation of GPX4 or downregulation of miR-744-5p/miR-615-3p attenuated the inhibitory effect of propofol on CR to Cis. In vivo, propofol inhibited tumor growth and CR to Cis by upregulating miR-744-5p/miR-615-3p and inhibiting GPX4 to induce ferroptosis. In summary, propofol inhibited GPX4-mediated ferroptosis and reduces CR of NSCLC cells to Cis through the miR-744-5p/miR-615-3p axis.

miR-338-3p targeted the 3' untranslated regions (3'UTR) of SLC1A5 for its inhibition and degradation, and high glucose downregulated SLC1A5 by upregulating miR-338-3p in RPE cells. Next, the miR-338-3p inhibitor and SLC1A5 overexpression vectors were delivered into the RPE cells, and the following gain- and loss-of-function experiments validated that both miR-338-3p ablation and SLC1A5 upregulation abrogated the regulating effects of high glucose on cell proliferation, viability, ferroptosis and ROS production in RPE cells.

Overexpression of PCAT1 inhibited ferroptosis and increased docetaxel resistance, which could be attenuated by PCAT1 knockdown. Furthermore, we revealed that PCAT1 inhibited ferroptosis by activating solute carrier family 7-member 11 (SLC7A11) expression via reducing iron accumulation and subsequent oxidative damage. Mechanistically, we demonstrated that PCAT1 interacted with c-Myc and increased its protein stability using nucleotides 1093-1367 of PCAT1 and 151-202 amino acids of c-Myc protein, thereby transcriptionally promoting SLC7A11 expression. In addition, PCAT1 facilitated SLC7A11 expression by competing for microRNA-25-3p. Finally, transcription factor AP-2 gamma (TFAP2C) activated PCAT1 expression at the transcriptional level to reduce ferroptosis susceptibility and enhance chemoresistance.

Chromatin immunoprecipitation and dual-luciferase assays showed that binding of IRF7 to the miR-375-3p promoter inhibited miR-375-3p expression, and miR-375-3p suppressed SLC11A2 transcription. The rescue experiments revealed that knockdown of miR-375-3p neutralized the role of silencing IRF7 in alleviating ferroptosis of colonic ECs. Overall, IRF7 upregulated SLC11A2 transcription by inhibiting miR-375-3p expression, thereby prompting ferroptosis of colonic ECs and UC progression in DSS-treated mice.

USC-Exo treatment improved kidney injury and ameliorated ferroptosis in IRI-induced AKI mouse models. USC-Exo were rich in lncRNA TUG1, which suppressed ferroptosis in HK-2 cells exposed to H/R. Mechanistically, lncRNA TUG1 regulates the stability of ACSL4 mRNA by interacting with RNA-binding protein SRSF1. In addition, SRSF1 upregulation or ACSL4 downregulation partially reversed the protective effect of lncRNA TUG1 on ferroptosis in H/R-treated HK-2 cells. Further, ACSL4 upregulation partially reversed TUG1's repression on kidney injury and ferroptosis in IRI-induced AKI mice.

We demonstrated that MALAT1 served as a competing endogenous RNA of miR-145-5p to regulate the expression of MUC1, a suppressor of ferroptosis. MALAT1 knockdown-mediated ferroptotic cell death and MUC1 downregulation could be abrogated by inhibition of miR-145-5p. In addition, miR-145-5p inhibition-mediated ferroptotic cell death could be abolished by MUC1 knockdown. Furthermore, erastin-induced ferroptosis shrunk endometriotic lesions via the MALAT1/miR-145-5p/MUC1 axis in vivo. Taken together, our data indicate that knockdown of MALAT1 facilitates ferroptosis upon erastin treatment via miR-145-5p/MUC1 signaling.

During H1N1 infection, the active form of ATP6V0A2 is reduced, which may be related to a decrease in lysosomal function. This type of cell death, Lysosome dependent cell death, which is related to lysosomes, has also been observed and significantly promotes H1N1-induced cell death. The ATP6V0A2 might be involved in Lysosome dependent cell death.

ALOX15 plays a critical role in maintaining skin health and its absence can disrupt skin homeostasis and may contribute to the development of skin diseases.

Low concentrations of boron can promote cell proliferation and differentiation by inhibiting the expression of FTH1, reducing iron ion accumulation and ROS production in cells, and thereby reducing cell death. In contrast, high concentrations of boron can increase ROS production by promoting the expression of FTH1, inducing apoptosis and necrosis.

SMPD1 is found to be involved in Necroptosis by delaying cell death through membrane repair. SMPD1 is an acid enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of sphingomyelin to generate ceramide. During Necroptosis, the activity of SMPD1 increases, inducing membrane repair and suppressing cell death.

Pyroptosis is a newly discovered type of programmed cell death, and CYCS can be involved in the apoptotic process of pyroptosis.

Wedelolactone  can up-regulate the expression of GPX4 by promoting its transcriptional activity thereby inhibiting cell lipid peroxidation, reducing cell death. The downregulation of GPX4 activity leads to lipid peroxidation and cell death, which in turn promotes the formation of Pyroptosis. The up-regulation of GPX4 by Wed plays a role in counteracting Pyroptosis. In addition, it was found that Wed can protect the pancreas and lungs from AP damage by up-regulating the expression of GPX4.

PLCG1 is an important step in phospholipid peroxidation-induced Gasdermin D (GSDMD)-mediated pyroptosis. PLCG1 is a crucial signaling molecule in inflammatory response, and its activation triggers the hydrolysis of membrane phospholipids and the generation of inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate. In GSDMD-mediated pyroptosis, the production of phospholipid peroxidation can activate PLCG1, leading to the N-terminal cleavage and activation of GSDMD. This process may be related to PLCG1's phosphoinositide pathway and calcium elevation.
